Column Comment.0: LITHOLOGY LOG ID: A unique identifier for a descriptive record of lithology.
Column Comment.1: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.2: DEPTH OBSERVATION NUMBER: unique identifier for the depth interval for this lithinterval. Use LITH LOG to get the top and base depths.
Column Comment.3: LITHOLOGIC ROCK TYPE: Type of rock comprising a significant portion of theinterval. For example, the predominant rock type in the interval may be coal, or ooliticlimestone or calcareous sandstone.
Column Comment.4: ROCK TYPE OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique sequence number enablingstorage of multiple descriptions for descriptive logs.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: CLASSIFICATION: Textural or other rock classification eg. packstone, litharenite
Column Comment.7: CLASSIFICATION MODIFIER: Adjective to modify rock name such as Oolitic, quartz
Column Comment.8: LITHOLOGIC CONSOLIDATION: Consolidation or induration of the rock sample.Induration of a rock sample (sandstone) refers to its resistance to physicaldisaggregation and does not necessarily refer to hardness of the constituent grains.Common types of consolidation (induration) are, dense, hard, medium hard, soft,spongy or friable.
Column Comment.9: MUD LOG COLOR: Observed colors resulting from llithologic analysis, such asfluorescence_color (Color of hydrocarbon as viewed in ultraviolet light.) cut_color(Color of hydrocarbon extracted by reagent/solvent in ultraviolet light.
Column Comment.10: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.11: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.12: MUD LOG COLOR: Observed colors resulting from llithologic analysis, such asfluorescence_color (Color of hydrocarbon as viewed in ultraviolet light.) cut_color(Color of hydrocarbon extracted by reagent/solvent in ultraviolet light.
Column Comment.13: FLOURESCENCE DISTRIBUTION: Distribution of hydrocarbon fluorescence
Column Comment.14: FLUORESCENCE RATE: Rate at which fluorescent streamers are emitted from rockchip
Column Comment.15: Reverse Engineered from column FRAMEWORK_PERCENT of tableLITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.16: Reverse Engineered from column MATRIX_PERCENT of table LITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.17: OIL STAIN: the type of oil stain observed in the rock sample. For example, the oilstain can be described as fair live oil, questionable, etc
Column Comment.18: PERMEABILITY QUALIFICATION: Permeability class based on qualitative visualestimate
Column Comment.19: Reverse Engineered from column POROSITY_GRADE_PERCENT of tableLITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.20: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.21: PRIMARY POROSITY TYPE: Primary type of porosity
Column Comment.22: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.23: LITHOLOGIC COLOR: Basic color or color adjective of lithologic components suchas red, grey, blue etc.
Column Comment.24: Reverse Engineered from column RESIDUE_PERCENT of table LITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.25: ROCK CLASSIFICATION SCHEME: The rock classification scheme used to namethe rock type. For example, the Folk classification scheme uses the terms, arkose,quartzarenite, etc. The Dunham classification scheme uses the terms mudstone,wackestone, etc.
Column Comment.26: LITHOLOGIC ROCK MATRIX: Type of fine grain material filling voids between largergrains. The grained particles in a poorly sorted sedimentary rock. Matrix can be finegrained sandstone, siltstone, shale, etc.
Column Comment.27: ROCK PROFILE: Identifies the type of rock weathering or borehole profile associatedwith the particular described interval. Examples of the rock profiles can be recessive,cliff, etc.
Column Comment.28: ROCK TYPE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE: Relative abundanceof each color rank (first,second, third: 1, 2, 3) or as a ranked magnitude (abundant, common, rare).
Column Comment.29: Reverse Engineered from column ROCK_TYPE_PERCENT of tableLITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.30: LITHOLOGIC ROUNDING: Classifies the shape of the rock components. This istypically used in describing clastic sedimentary rocks. There are an almost infinitenumber of variations in the shapes of grain size, but the most common classes aresharp, angular, subangular, rounded or globular.
Column Comment.31: SECONDARY POROSITY TYPE: Secondary porosity type
Column Comment.32: Reverse Engineered from column SOLID_HCARBON_PERCENT of tableLITH_ROCK_TYPE
Column Comment.33: SOLID HYDROCARBON TYPE: Type of solid hydrocarbon type such as pyrobitumen
Column Comment.34: LITHOLOGIC SORTING: Identifies the type of sorting associated with the principalrock being described. This feature is most important in coarse clastic rocks andcommon examples are well, medium or poorly sorted.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
